text: Proposal: I love this channel, but I’d like to try an experiment. What if for one week only, we posted positive changes within the industry/worldwide with diversity?
if you want us to shut up, just say so
(kidding kidding)
There’s no tongue sticking out emoji!
i like the idea a lot, even if it means we dont have as much to say
It’s not forever, but just for a week!
Ugh there is a tongue sticking out emoji, but not a pouty one.
<@U02F9CXTL|jstrand> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/jstrand/F265SL2HJ/carebears_and_cousins_art.jpg|carebears_and_cousins_art.jpg>
Wtf
see, look at that, Jason Strand is IN
<https://www.dropbox.com/s/edng0lvg8820cbx/Strand.png>
<@U02F9CXTL> ^
<@U0J6TE0CA> i love the idea of switching the focus to the positive. might be a little more quiet here, but i think its good to practice
I’m not a big fan since I think it discourages anyone who is dealing with the suboptimal, but I’m happy to join the experiment
how easy is it to gauge if something is positive though?
Achievements, accomplishments, breakthroughs, etc. That kind of stuff
maybe we target a focus on the positive, but save space for people to share things that might not fit into that bucket if they feel they need to (to megans point, which is a good one)
I’d love to try it just for a week
Not forever
im already on the hunt for some positive things to share :slightly_smiling_face:
i mean, when other people share things like what midori posted above it gives me a positive response because i’m able to relate and feel supported by experiences others have had that i have shared
so even though it’s about what’s not a breakthrough or achievement it seems like a positive posting to me
also: generally not opposed, just trying to understand what the purpose behind the experiment would be

Not saying we can’t go back to more broad topics. I just want to try an experiment w/ an expiration date. 

I know some people find this channel overwhelming & intimidating, afraid of saying “the wrong thing” for a number of reasons. That theme has come up over & over from a number of people. That prompted a curiosity in me to see if this experiment would help.
Not meant to censor, but more want to see how celebrating accomplishments & the like might shake things up.

I’ll go first. I had NO CLUE some of these were directed by women!

 <http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/great-movies-directed-by-women/>

attachments.title: 27 great movies directed by women
attachments.text: Female directors may still have a long way to go achieving equal representation in Hollywood, but their films speak for themselves

text: <@U0J6TE0CA> - sounds like a generally good idea. I think it’s easy to feel really hopeless when it’s so easy to find things to critique.

I do like the idea of celebrating things going right, and I’m down for setting aside some time for us to that. At the same time, I would like Uncorked as a community to continue work on the hard parts of this. Not knowing the right thing to say is no fun, and it leads to mistakes, but I’d really like for all of us stare these tough things down together
I guess I just want to make sure we turn away when things get tricky
^ Agreed to both points.
I think a lot of us are super passionate (myself included) about this sort of stuff, and if it’s new to others it can come across as intimidating or aggressive.
Want to try somethig new
Also, I think folks being afraid of saying the wrong thing points to an issue of the reaction/perception of saying the wrong thing
in many cases, that is exactly how it should?

that is, saying the wrong thing could be seen as a growth opportunity.
or a chance to personally “debug” :wink:

text: I know we’ve sort of moved on from this, but it’s been rattling around in my head and I felt like I needed finish my point which basically: I don’t want this channel, or the DI group, or the efforts UCS puts into diversity inclusion to ever be motivated by the comfort or fragility of those aren’t experiencing problems. It sort of breaks my heart to think that someone here might be facing something and would self-censor for fear of making someone uncomfortable. Further, I don’t ever want someone to feel like in order to bring something up they also need to have a solution. For me, I want people to feel like UCS is place where one can simply say “this is a thing I’m seeing, or feeling, or thinking” without worry that their experience is putting someone else out. The reality is that if you’ve (me) been privileged enough in this life to not face discrimination or hostility or repression than you (me) likely don’t have a fully developed vocabulary to address these issues immediately, which is what makes it uncomfortable, and what makes it critical that we get more comfortable being uncomfortable.
Not intending to change the channel, I think sharing & exposing these issues are important. Simply trying an experiment.

No, no - I think it’s a good experiment and I’m not trying to stifle it. Mostly I just want to make sure that we don’t start making our choices (especially around DI) in ways could feel disempowering to those whose may want to share experiences or ideas that might make some people uncomfortable
I think we're on the same page!
